clues.text: AKA "America’s Dairyland", it’s one of the leading U.S. states in milk production
1 of this unit of milk weighs about 8 pounds
A Frenchman created this process that kills microorganisms in milk by heating it
This type of sugar that's less sweet than sucrose is found only in milk
In 1856 Gail Borden received a patent for his process to do this to milk
Bush-Cheney called Edwards Kerry's second choice, meaning this Republican was his first
George W. Bush won 91% of the vote in Massachusetts (unfortunately for him it was in this contest)
Most of the over 50,000 signatures he submitted to try to get on the Michigan ballot were collected by the GOP
In a July 23 speech to this league, the President asked if the Democrats take black voters for granted
This Florida senator was the first Democratic candidate to drop out of the race
In the 19th century a new breed of terrier was named for this clergyman
In "Nightmares & Dreamscapes" this author wrote, "I believe there is an unseen world all around us"
In 1999 this rapper-turned-actress turned talk show host
Columbia chief Harry Cohn advised this actor to change his last name to avoid negative review puns
An ad in a 1973 paper brought this lead guitarist together with Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley & Peter Criss
One of the principal exports of Seychelles is copra, the dried white flesh of this fruit
From about 1500 to 1750 the Seychelles served mainly as a hiding place for these people
The Seychelles uses this unit of currency, which is also used in Pakistan, Nepal & Sri Lanka
Seychelles is an example of this grouping of a large number of islands on a vast sheet of sea
This Portuguese navigator, the first European to reach India by sea, discovered the Seychelles in 1502
A tree that's a national symbol of Slovenia, or a Texan U.S. president's first name
Loudly, raucously sound out George Orwell's original last name
A critiquer of pure reason who died in 1804, or a response indicating you're unable to grasp his philosophy
In "A hymn to God the Father", this metaphysical poet makes punning use of this synonym for "finished"
Sadly for him, the 17th century gunpowder plotter wasn't quite as sly as the animal
On October 26, 1881 this took place at Tombstone's OK Corral
William Congreve wrote, "Women are like tricks by" this "of hand, which, to admire, we should not understand"
As a noun, it's a zero; as a pronoun, it's nothing
Samuel F.B. Morse could have told you that it's a past tense & a past participle of work
Abbreviated dwt., it's equal to 24 grains, or 1/20 of a troy ounce
Social insects, termites live in groups of a few hundred to several million called these
Dioxide of this element, symbol Cr, is used to make recording tape for cassettes
The Cassini spacecraft is scheduled to study this planet & send a probe to the surface of its moon Titan
The name of this pivoted frame for the combustion chamber & nozzle of a rocket sounds like Macy's one-time rival
This biologist first gained acclaim for writing in 1937 with her article "Undersea" in the Atlantic Monthly

rounds.comments: (Alex: You must give us the first and the last name of the stars.)

clues.text:
Hail to the chief:
ART MEN SHINE

She "presses" on:
SOLE JAIL NANNY

We're still "laugh-in" at her:
O MY ILL LINT

Quite a "lady":
DANCING CART HONKS

He's Toby Z:
HARD CHIC RIFFS
One of these large birds is featured in "Les Maries de la Tour Eiffel" (reminds me of "Fantasia")
The "Bluebird Pas de Deux" is performed at Princess Aurora's wedding in this fairy tale ballet
Gelsey Kirkland starred in the 1972 version of "The Song of" this nocturnal bird
Tamara Karsavina won the role of this title bird in a 1910 ballet because Anna Pavlova didn't like the music
Created for Anna Pavlova, this famous ballet solo is a lot shorter than "Swan Lake"
The avant-garde author of "Three Lives", her home was a salon for emerging artists such as Picasso & Braque
While in Paris, poet & critic Ezra Pound helped little-known talent T.S. Eliot edit this 1922 poem
This "Fanfare for the Common Man" composer sold his first work while studying with Nadia Boulanger in Paris
Alexander Calder made one of his first wire sculptures in the image of this expatriate singer/dancer
During his self-exile, he voiced the strife of black Americans in books like 1961's "Nobody Knows My Name"
Published in 1976, her last Miss Marple case, "Sleeping Murder", was actually written during WWII
She introduced Mr. & Mrs. Dalloway in her first novel, "The Voyage Out"
Chapters in this novel include "Wickfield and Heep" & "Mr. Micawber's Gauntlet"
Published in 1590, "The Legend of the Red Cross Knight" is the first of 6 books in this poetic epic
She's the heroine of the long-banned 18th century novel "Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure"
This Debby Boone hit was No. 1 on the Top 40 chart for 10 weeks, longer than any other song of the 1970s
His No. 1 R&B hits include "Papa Don't Take No Mess Part 1"
Her 1996 hit "Because You Loved Me" topped the adult contemporary charts for an amazing 19 weeks
In 1995 she had 2 songs debut at the top of the charts; one was a duet with Boyz II Men
He wrote Bread's only No. 1 hit, "Make It With You", as well as the title track to the 1977 film "The Goodbye Girl"

rounds.text: After a large French army was wiped out by yellow fever on this island in 1802, Napoleon decided to sell Louisiana
